description.text:
Current Version: 1.4
Date: 2013-02-20
I am required to write documentation for equipment and devices I build and design so that others can use them proficiently. Hence, here is a formatted sheet which you can fill with information specific to your printer such as Equipment Description, Person Responsible, Authorised Users, Expected Performance & Settings. I keep mine in an A4 clear folder sheet on the side of the printer so no-one has any excuse for not having access to the correct settings. Note: This A4 clear folder sheet also serves as 1 of the sides parts of the Thing-o-Matic Side Panel Plastic Covers http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12475 Some samples are provided (the filenames that end in "A.doc") and the most recent blank template (filename ends in "Ablank.doc"). I hope this will be of some use to you.

1A. Print it out
2A. Fill it in
OR
1B. Fill it in
2A. Print it out
THEN
  • Attach to your printer or use as first page in laboratory folder/printer manual
  • Reduce incidences of unauthorised users attempting to use machine they don't understand with incorrect settings
  • Happier, more hassle free 3D Printing for all!

i have done them in PETG

description.text:
This is a slightly-modified version of rookiewookie's filament guide. Changes:
  • Spacing between the mounting "forks" reduced to about 5 mm
  • Length of the slot between the forks deepened by a few milimeters
  • thickness of the arm increased by 1 mm or so
  • Rotated the model to sit flat on the plate
    • You may need to file the forks a bit (to increase the gap), to fit your particular frame.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

30%

Notes: Watch the curve on the left (e.g. other end of the forks), as it's technically an overhang and may be difficult to print without adequate supports, especially with PLA.
It's sized to exactly 5 mm between the forks, but some sanding/filing of that slot may be necessary to remove stringies and related artifacts.
Just used blender to import the original STL, tweak, and re-export.

description.text: I have try many designs of indicator mounts this is the best one  , i design it to be  stable on the metal rods and you can get an accurate reading from the indicator , good luck every body
After you print the model just add magnets to it and you are ready to go .

Update 05-16-16: Created a second Skeletonized version which has an extra bracer bar on the back so it's a lil more durable (although probably not needed depending on application). Update 05-15-16: Printed off the Skeletonized version with 15% infill and no supports and it came out great! Pic added of the print resting in my hand using Glow in the Dark PLA Filament. Update 02-11-16: Added a Skeletonized version for quicker printing. May print about 50% faster that the full one. Haven't printed one off yet so not sure how well it will work. Will update when I do print one. Basically a mounting platform for 4 strips of LED Light Strips to make your own LED Light Bars or Workshop Lights. It's scaled to about 50mm in length which was the length of the 3LED strips cutting points. So you can print it as many times as you want (or scale out the length) for longer strips of lights. I printed one off, and wired up and installed 4 strips to show what it should look like when you build and mount the light strips to it. The plan is to make some LED Lightbars to mount on the ceiling of my garage to replace the aging Flourescent Tube fixtures. Feel free to adjust the Z-Axis as you see fit to get the length you need, but most LED Light Strips I have seen adhere to the 3LED's before a break you can cut with scissors at 50mm in length. The light strips I used are 5050SMD White LED's, Amazon Item: http://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B00JQV6Q4I Printed on a Printrbot Simple Metal using Hatchbox Silver PLA. I printed at 0.3mm and 15% infill which makes it extremely solid, but it could probably be done with less infill. This is my first 3D Design ever. I literally created this about an hour after downloading Sketchup, so go easy one me! I also am working on (last image) a 7 strip version which would make out quite the bright light, as well as coupling tabs to snap multiple prints together, but I'm still learning with the modelling software how to really make that work.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

No

0.3mm

15%

comments.text: Question from a novice.  Just got a Lulzbot Mini printer and this was one of the first objects I tried to print.  It's a wonderful design.  However, I'm having problems with both sleeves.  For my first attempt, I  used HIPs filament, that came with the printer.  I am using the Cura software recommended by Lulzbot and for my first attempt, I tried it without supports.  The two sleeves were a mess.  Other than that, it came out very well and once I trimmed it up some by hand, it still looked pretty nice.  However, I wanted to try to print it better.  For my second attempt, I used ABS filament, and used supports in Cura - "Touching Buildplate" for the support, which the software says is what is used most of the time.  It added support for the hand not holding the staff and improved that hand, but it was still not perfect.  It did not add support for the sleeve of the hand holding the staff, and that side ended up being just as much a mess as the first attempt. So, it was better than my first attempt, but still had problems.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

A high bypass fan inspired by Rolls-Royce's Trent series turbofans. Designed in CATIA, sliced in Simplify3D, and printed on a Makergear M2. The fan blades print separately from the disk and are designed to slide in, just like a real fan. The blades can stand up on their own, and the whole fan can also balance on the blade tips as shown in the first picture. This was a totally unintentional bonus feature and would've been difficult to design for. The white spiral stripe is printed flat, then dipped in hot water to soften and form around the black spinner cone - this step is tricky, but the end result is amazing. The clearances and gaps between the parts are as optimized as I could get them, so that parts aren't too tight or too loose. Be careful about where the slicer assigns the start and end of each layer, especially for the fan blades - I recommend starting/ending each layer at either the blade's leading edge or trailing edge. You can see on one of the fan blades in the picture where the layer seam went diagonally across the back. This model begs to be printed in multiple colors! Enjoy! If anybody has problems with parts not fitting, please comment and I can upload a revised file. For source files, I uploaded this to GrabCad as well: https://grabcad.com/library/3d-printable-high-bypass-fan-1

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.15mm

Infill:

15%

Notes: Printed using Hatchbox PLA. I didn't need rafts on anything, but I did have brims on the fan blades and annulus fillers. Fan blades don't require supports. The disk's supports are a nightmare to remove, but they're necessary.
Designed using pictures. Blueprints and drawings from engine manufacturers are never publicly available for obvious reasons.

I recommend printing with Supports, because the "E" could cause unwanted spaghetti!

title: Panasonic SA-HT750 Speaker Stand Coupling
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
My Panasonic SA-HT750 surround sound system is great. The only problem with it are the speaker stands, specifically the plastic coupling piece. As you can see in the photo, they break. There is not too much to them, just some thin, injection molded plastic.
One was completely destroyed, the other had just started cracking. I took the 'good' one as a reference and tried to model something that would do the same thing but also look okay. My coupling doesn't have a feature that goes on the inside of the stand tube. I thought about this and didn't think such a feature created much of an advantage. I did beef up the thickness of the perimeter a bit to compensate for the lack of any ID support. The ID has to be open anyways to allow the speaker wire to pass through.
I printed with 30% infill. This was plenty. 
FYI, the speaker stand poles were 0.750 inches in diameter.

author: captainserious

title: Dyson DC35/DC44 wall mount/holder extension & OpenSCAD end-bit model

description.text:
The DC35/DC44 Animal comes with a wall mount charger/accessories holder. It also comes with an extra accessory, which doesn't fit the accessories holder :(
.
A better redesigned version now available at Shapeways.com
. (also a wall mount for Dyson V8 tools)
.
I have reworked the design with a better clip to firmly hold the accessories, and tailored to the materials and printing capabilities at Shapeways. The final design has now been printed & tested.
The new design is not suited to FDM printers.
.
This Thingiverse Version:
. So I modelled the end section of the accessories and the female end of the accessories holder in OpenSCAD to make an extension, like a double adapter.
It should be good for the other DC series models too, like the DC59. You could also use the ends as the basis of a custom nozzle.
Use View Full Size for a better view.
.
This version is a Work-In-Progress:
.
A. originally the plate was half as thick and was too flexible, as I had already glued the bits on, I just printed a second plate and glued it to the bottom. The plate here is thicker, but I have not printed one to confirm its rigidity. If you print one can someone let me know if its ok.
B. WIP as the tab I designed (intending it to clip into the recess and retain the accessory) not doing a good job and tending to break off (in ABS - haven't tried PLA). As the holders point upward the retainer is not required. It would have been good if it worked, to have some accessories pointing down too, could have had less width to the extension. If anyone has any idea for a better mechanism please let me know. I included a 1-wide plate if anyone wants to try a one up/one down extension.
I have given up for now...

Print
1 dyson...inside.stl,
2 dyson...outside.stl, &
1 dyson...plate_2.stl.
(the inside/outside are the ones split in two for better printing, I included the ...whole.stl versions for those lucky enough to have printer types which handle overhang, or who like to use support)
The plate has markings to align the three other parts for acetone/gluing to the plate.
Fit the small power head into the right slot, the extension in the left, and the crevice & combination tools on top of the extension.

title: Makerbot i3Pro print cooling fan.  Geeetech MK8 extruder, blower fan setup.

description.text:
16Jan16 @ 20:16
This is a print cooling fan that I designed for my Makerbot i3Pro.  I could not find another one that I could get to work with my hotend (mostly due to nozzle orientation and height), so I decided to design my own.  
I had a hard time printing my first nozzle design because I had no print cooling capabilities, so I modified it to be printed easier without cooling. The last thing I want to do (and I haven't simply because I have been lazy) is cut away all the extra support that I had to add to make it print correctly without a bunch of overhangs.  I'll get to that soon and will upload a cleaner version that you can print after you have this one installed and working.  
I used a generic 12V 50mm Blower  Fan 5015 (50x50x15mm) that I found on ebay.  Works great so far.  I raided my R/C parts bin for various fasteners.  Sorry for the lack of details, but my printer is now in my closet and I have had too many ales to get it out right now and measure all the bolts.  
I printed all the parts using Makergeek grey PLA set at 207C in the hotend and 60C for the bed.  
To get this to work, I had to move the wiring to the other side of the print head, and I also had to rotate the extruder motor either 90 or 180 degrees, can't remember which.  No big deal there.  Also please keep in mind that I designed this around my particular hotend nozzle placement, which might be lower of higher depending on how far the nozzle throat is threaded in. I would suggest adjusting the nozzle throat rather than altering the nozzle dimension, but that's up to you.  
Sorry for the orientation of the STL files.  I rotated them in Slic3r but forgot to change the Solidworks source files.  If you have trouble with them let me know and I will upload new ones that have them orientated the right way.
Leave me a comment and let me know what you think!

A fairly simple amplifier device for airsoft guns with 14mm threaded barrels. It should print cleanly without a brim, raft or supports.
This will convert the sound of the airsoft shot from a puff or thud into a higher pitch snap or pop, much like the commercially available versions (madbull/socom gear KX3 and KFH amplifiers). Effects will be different based on how much air the airsoft gun is putting out, and where the barrel ends.
For reference, my test platform has a Woverine airsoft HPA engine inside, so air volume output is slightly higher than on an electric airsoft gun; my inner barrel also ends right at the crown of the outer barrel, which is very close to the optimal distance for this particular amplifier design (optimal is 1-2mm longer than the crown of the outer barrel). The design is self-threading, add a drop of WD 40 or silicone lubricant on the threads of the outer barrel and screw the amplifier on. The first time will be a bit difficult, but after you remove it and blow the dust out of the newly cut threads it should go on easy. I found that it is much easier to get the AMP to go on straight if you use a razor knife to cut a light bevel on the bottom edge where the 14mm hole is located, this is recommended for every one, but it might be required if you use a brim to print.
Print at 1.01 scale to account for ABS shrinkage, printing at 1.00 scale should still work but it will make the first attachment slightly harder.
Make sure your printer is well calibrated, as the wall behind the indented lettering is fairly thin and can be prone to delamination failures or breaks in the wall on machines that aren't well calibrated. See it in action here: https://youtu.be/VLO7v527Aqg

author: spooner2011

title: MPCNC Clip-On Z Tower Connection Mount

description.text:
I am working on converting the connections on my MPCNC over to RJ45s. For the connections that need beefier wires, like the extruder heater, I plan to use molex connectors. I use my MPCNC with many different tools, so I want as many options as possible on the z tower for connecting to them.
This thing clips on to the z motor mount and provide mounting places for two RJ45s and a four-pin molex connector. There are also eight screw-down terminal points in the back for even more connection options. There are numerous holes all around the frame to make it easy to guide the wire bundles using small bundle ties. There are three holes near each RJ45 mount for inserting a tool to press the catch to insert or release the connector.
This is a work in progress, but this version snaps in place well and is quite usable - I'm just playing with the size of the RJ45 holes to print right on my printer - so I thought I'd upload it, in case anyone is looking for something similar.
I'm printing it in PLA at .3 layer height and 25% infill. I had done a 10% infill but it broke while clipping it on. It needs to print with supports.

comments.text: I was looking at doing something similar, but using db25 connectors.  I was intending to have each tool-head have the appropriate pins soldered in as appropriate for the given tool-head (fans, lasers, extruder steppers, thermistors, hot-end heaters, etc...) as well as providing a 3.3v, 5v and 12v bus lines.  The heavier gage connection pins can handle the current of hot-end heaters, and there's enough pins to facilitate the devices I have in mind.

author: HarryK4247

description.text: It holds things steady while you work.

Edit: 5-13-14
That lead photo always bothered me. It was taken with the camera's "macro" setting and if the subject is too distant, results in a distorted fish-eye view. It looks as if the bracket is curved, bent, or a poor fit... but it's actually straight and square with the world....
,,,,,
The file is SAE and may appear very tiny in some (metric) software.
To convert to Metric, scale up by a factor of 25.4
,,,,,,,
This spindle lock could be used in conjunction with some sort of an indexing mechanism.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:124909
It will hold the spindle steady so you can perform light duty operations on a stationary workpiece. While it manages a pretty firm grip, I hesitate to call this a "lock". Using a torque wrench on the spindle with the thing clamped down required around 15 pound-feet to budge the spindle. That's strong but it's not exactly locked. I think the clamp-bolt (6x1mm x 50mm) could have been tightened to get a few more pounds of torque, but I didn't want to test it to the point of destruction. Maybe another time.
The hold is very solid, and should be adequate for many operations.. layouts, grinding, etc... but I don't know about something like milling. Needs experimentation. I used 0.25mm layers, "solid" fill. "Normal" quality, with a raft. It's near a 2 hour print and uses 45 grams of material. I looked but found no easy way to lock the spindle on these mini lathes. There's just nothing to hang on to. You can't drill into the hardened spindle or chucks. Most people engage the gears / leadscrew etc but I wanted something dedicated. One downside to this method is a couple of attachment holes must be drilled and tapped into the headstock casting.
The upside is you don't need big fat bolts or a lot of threads to hold the plastic part. I used a #9 drill, went 20mm deep and tapped for two short 6x1mm bolts. That's plenty. The holding band could be much wider for more strength (maybe), but I designed it just narrow enough to temporarily park it out of the way, back behind the standard (80mm) chuck. This way you can use the lathe without completely removing the lock.
This might be handy when working between centers, locking and unlocking, or on some project where you don't want to remove and replace the workpiece just to get the lock off and use the lathe.
I still wouldn't leave this lock on there during normal day-to-day operations. Murphy's law.

comments.text:
Terminus, many thanks for your reply. As I said I am very new to this (and stupid).
My printer is a Home built Prusa Mendel, Using Pronterface/Slic3r software.
I have now regenerated the g code with support material added. ( I didn't understand that bit).
Print is now underway and looking good.
All the other things I have printed so far, have been flat on the build platform.
I was surprised to see that your STL only measured 4+mm, my chucks are 100mm, so I have had to scale it up somewhat!
Again, Many thanks.
comments.author: redbaron

comments.text: My STL files look small because I will always be more comfortable using Imperial measurements, and that is my "preference" when designing with Blender software. My 3 inch circle must be a 3mm circle when imported to metric software. (My chuck is the standard 3 inch (80mm). You must have a 4 inch. I'd like to get a 4" 4-jaw...)
comments.author: redbaron

comments.text:
Great stuff, It's a whisker undersize, but all the better for it.
Due to up-scaling, the mounting bracket needs modifying, narrowing and new slots milled in it and needs a 10mm packer under it, no problem as I have a 10mm thick steel universal mounting plate for the top of the headstock under construction.
Many thanks.
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text: My pleasure. I'm glad you at least got something out of it.

A wall-mount adapter for the Playstation 4 Dualshock 4 controller. The original USB cable clips into this thing. My cable clipped in very snugly, but if yours isn't so clicky, maybe a dab of glue would help? The USB plug clicks into the controller pretty firmly too, so I'm pretty happy leaving my controller hanging from it. You might not be, especially if there are small kids around. This pairs well with my PS4 Wall Mount. That design leaves enough room behind the PS4 to hide most of the USB cable behind it.

title: 3/8" Dowel rod clip, snap, hinge... whatever.

description.text:
This is a clip / hinge to mount a piece of 3/8 inch dowel rod. I have provided a 1" and 1/2" version. I needed it to snap an exhaust shroud around a window to vent the ABS fumes out of the house. I am using the 1/2' item as a clip and the 1" item as a hinge. They printed very nicely with no supports.
*** After using this as a snap for a few times, I found that it would break due to the tightness of the loop opening. I have uploaded new files. Two are half inch and one inch hinges or holders with the loop opening similar to the original since the intent is to snap it in and leave it. The other two are half inch and one inch snaps with a wider opening to reduce the stress on the joint when repeatedly snapping it in and out. I am also doubling the infill to 50% for my next print.

FlashForge Creator Pro

description.text:
This is a simple clip-on Z-probe for the Rostock Max (V1, might fit V2, I don't know) that uses standard limit switches.  It cilps onto the arm axle on one end, and the extruder platform on the other end.

description.text:
OpenSCAD model for magnetic button/indicator - basically a disc with a socket for common cylindrical magnets.  The STL and OpenSCAD source is for a 30mm diameter button with a 12.75x3.2mm magnet, but it's customizer-enabled so you should be able to modify it easily.
My initial use case is as a dishwasher clean/dirty indicator - I wasn't happy with any of the more complex ones I found.  For that, I printed the cap in a different color so just flipping the button over indicates the state.  Another idea would be to put a design on the cap and/or button body, provided they are printed with enough height (taller button or thinner magnet).  A small amount of glue will hold the magnet and cap in place permanently, but I found the cap to be snug enough to hold everything when sticking it against a dishwasher or fridge.  Sticking it to another magnet, however, was enough to remove the cap and magnet.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

One of the classic Thunderbirds by Gerry Anderson. Based on a model by Simon C. https://3dwarehouse.sketchup.com/model.html?id=4557e6fb3873dd55867979b8521212be. Both hi-res and reduced-resolution "plated" versions optimized for FDM printers are included, as well as separate files for the top, bottom, and antenna groups. (You may wish to remove the antennae and add supports to make the hi-res and "smoothed" models 3D-printer ready, as I have done with the lower-res plated version.) 2015/1/18 Update: I've made the antennae thicker to make them easier to print.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.14 mm

Infill:

5% with at least 3 shells.

Notes: Remove the built-in support materials.
Glue the top and the lower antenna tower to the bottom part. Please note that the model is not intended to balance on the lower antenna tower -- I have found that the clear plastic tube in which Superglue is sold makes an unobtrusive and stable stand when positioned just behind the lower antenna.
Make the antenna struts from a straightened paperclip snipped into three pieces and insert into the holes provided (one at the front and two on the top), then attach the printed antenna parts. The model in the photos was printed in silver PLA and painted with acrylics.

I felt the Chroma battery terminals were a little too exposed when throwing them in my backpack so I made a quick and dirty cap to take care of the problem. I printed them at 30% infill 0.2mm layer. Feel free to let me know if you would like them changed in anyway and I'll try to accommodate the change.

remixed_from.title: Nozzle fan with snapfit for 50mm blower fan.

title: Type A Series 1 Pro Radial Cooling Blower Fan Mount

description.header: Type A Series 1 Pro Radial Cooling Blower Fan Mount
description.text:
This is an adaptation of the radial cooling blower fan duct designed by @esteevens for mounting on a Type A Series 1 Pro. This design produces both more direct and more evenly distributed cooling on the filament being deposited as the nozzle traverses through the print. You will need some M3 hardware (depends on your blower width) but I recommend M3 x 25mm for this particular blower I had and 2 x M3 x 8mm for the mounting to the heat sink. Please note that the Type A Series 1 Fan01 may use either 12V or a 24V PWM maximum voltage, and you should either select the blower fan voltage appropriately, or adjust the maximum fan setting value in your slicer (e.g. for running a fan at 12V on a 24V PWM you would run M106 S127. This can be configured in CURA. The other option may be to find a jumper, or modify the firmware to step-up/down the voltage. The original blower nozzle fan design by @esteevens can be found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1179737

description.header: Note: working fine printed in PLA even though there is no insulation around the nozzle.  If there is a problem with temp I would just recommend printing in a material with a higher transition temperature.

The Plug is designed so that if its a little too big it will give in the middle for a tight fit or if its a tad too small you can put a screw in it to make it stretch. Simple. pop the hanger and cap on one end of the PVC, feed through the spool then pop the hanger and cap on the other end! BOOM! you got a kick butt filament holder that can be any size you want!

I couldn't wait for the new X-Controller to come out so I made a laser cut case for my X-Carve electronics and I added a lot of the options to the base. The relay is internal and has two plugs with separate switches which allows each one to either be on/off or relay. There is an E-Stop and the start/hold/reset buttons are there. I also moved all the connections to the side and put the control switches on the front. This is my new alternative. I like the idea of it being underneath my machine so it takes up the least amount of table space now. The other reason for the change is I wanted more space for the electronics. It was getting way too crowded in the other one and now there is plenty of wires and air moving around. Here is the parts list for the buttons, switches, plugs. The electronics are all from inventables and the case is held together with a hand full of M3-40mm nuts and bolts.

title: Robo 3D Z-Axis Limit Switch Fine Adjustment

description.text:
**note, this is only applicable to fairly early Kickstarter Robo3D model. Later Kickstarter shipments and the R1 have a solution already in place.
This thing is a bracket to attach a screw to the z-axis motor mount of the robo3D to facilitate fine adjustment of the z-axis home position.
It is actually a remix to a mod posted by another Robo3D forum member, Cambo3D. Here is the link to the oritingal mod.
http://forums.robo3dprinter.com/index.php?threads/better-z-height-adjustment-mod.838/
The original mod is a great idea, but I wanted to avoid drilling into the injection molded part, so I created a bracket to use the same concept without permanently altering anything.

-Print part
-Screw 6-32 2" lg screw into hole. If you have a 6-32 tap, you may want to tap it first, but not absolutely necessary.
-Remove screw.
-mount to lower right corner motor mount (may need to acquire a longer screw depending on what your machine shipped with)
-raise z-axis
-Push z-axis limit switch bracket down to the rod mounts and turn by about 45 degrees
-Fasten bracket to lower right corner motor mount screw
-Install 6-32X2" screw.
-Adjust as needed to get a correct gap between the nozzle and the bed.

title: QAV180 (210) XT60 + Antenna mount, HS1184 cam mount, LED bar

description.text: Update: Camera mount strengthened some more.
Update: The camera mount got a new revision that sets the camera angle to 30° to save manual adjustment.

Update: The LED front mount was modified a bit. Better fit, and additional strength to act more like a bumper to protect the camera from taking a direct hit. Only 1g more weight.
LEDs used are these, btw: http://www.banggood.com/LED-Decoration-Board-Strip-3S-For-QAV250-Quadcopter-p-951108.html
Work fine on 4S too.
Update: Slightly adjusted the camera mount width. Use M2x5 or M2x6 screws to mount camera, 2xM3x8 + 2x M3 lock nut to attach the mount.

Currently doing a build based on a qav180 clone.
In order to fit the rear xt60/antenna mount, you have to cut off the original one. This can be done simply with a dremel, standard cutoff wheel, and a steady hand. Medium speed, go slow. I can't stand dangling battery connectors, so this cleans it up nicely. All parts printed in PETG. Use high infill for strength.
After test-fitting the XT60 (it should slide in fairly easily), apply a few drops of super glue on all four sides, slide it in, and let it dry for a few hours. Using that method, the only way to get it out was to break the mount along with it, so it should hold up good.

title: DJI Phantom 3 Landing Gear Extensions (3 different styles)

description.text:
While developing our payload drop hook (thing 1259564) for our DJI Phantom 3 quad copter, we realized that we needed landing gear extensions to provide clearance for the folded-up drop hook. We didn't want to re-invent the wheel, so to speak, so we chose Tanemahuta's "Phantom 3 Gimbal Guard to go" (thing 909566) design as our mounting base on which to mount our landing gear extensions. Many thanks to Tanemahuta for his design. So, to use our Phantom 3 landing extensions you will need the following:
2- H5 labs landing gear extensions (this design)
1- http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:909566 (P3 Gimbal Guard to go)
4- 4-40 x 1/2" long screws
4- 4-40 nuts Please reference the print settings for information on what we found worked best for us in printing the landing gear extensions. To assemble:
Press fit the landing gear extensions onto the P3 Gimbal Guard to go. align them so that they fit centered over the two beams that run next to and parallel to the original Phantom 3 landing gear bars (these run front-to-back). Reference attached photos for details. Once aligned, use a 7/64" drill bit to drill the four holes in the P3 Gimbal Guard to go - use the holes in the landing gear extensions as guides for drilling (reference attached photo to see how we drilled these holes using this method). Then, insert the 4-40 nuts in the indentations on the bottom of the landing gear extension arms. Finally, insert the 4-40 x 1/2" long screws so that they first pass through the holes drilled in the P3 Gimbal to go and then into the landing gear extensions (it's a good idea to use a small dab of removable loc-tite on the screw threads). Reference the attached picture showing the completed assembly. When ready, simply attach the modified P3 Gimbal to go to your Phantom 3 and you're good to go. UPDATE (2/8/2016): Added two new styles. Style 2 moves the landing gear legs to be inline with original lading pads. Style 3 is based on style 2 and a bit more radical (and most likely a more challenging print) in that it twists the landing gear legs 45 degrees out, which should keep it completely out of the camera's view. I have not attempted to print either of these new designs yet. I would appreciate feedback from anyone who tries to print and use these at it may be awhile before I get to it (strong gust of wind took out my Phantom 3, so I've a good many repairs to make :-). Best of luck to all.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

No

0.300mm

Infill:

50%

Notes: We used MakerGear PLA with a bed temperature of 70C and extruder temperature of 220C to print. No supports should be needed if printed in the orientation shown in the 3D model file.

remixed_from.author: RichRap
remixed_from.title: Quick-Fit X carriage and Extruder - LM8UU

description.header: I'm experimenting with the fantastic new MendelMax 2.0 from http://www.makerstoolworks.com/
description.text:
I've taken the DXF's available here:
http://github.com/Makers-Tool-Works/MendelMax-2.0/tree/master/Sources/dxf and Made (and modified) STL's with the intention of taking the MM2.0 back towards being a true RepRap instead of more of a RepStrap. [NOTE: 3mm wasn't sturdy enough for most STLs - 6mm works lovely for the most part, files are now sized and updated to V2.0,
Braces have been added where needed as well as a few new files...] These are neither a finished product nor an official release, they are purely here for anyone like myself that wishes to experiment with a 'more printable' version of the MM2... Both the Faceplates and the Y bed plate are oversized for a standard sized print bed (by a large margin, I'm afraid) - but everything else will fit nicely. If (for whatever reason) you have a machine capable of printing these, I would seriously recommend Z scaling all of these to at least 8mm thickness. [EDIT: Printable Y-bed plate now added - not as rigid as Alu, but works well in experimentation - i've yet to see if it warps over time though - be warned!] A few pieces like the electronics mount, and Z motor mounts have been braced and handed for added stability.
Still to do are the upper and lower triangles (though they don't seem to need it as yet)
I found that the X-carriage and the Idler arm need to be a little thicker and so I've scaled those up to 6mm thickness (like most of the STL's)
Furthermore, I've included a modded MM2 Z bushing holder that'll take a 10mm bushing, or LM10UU linear bearing (might need a dab of glue depending on your printer accuracy)
Also a 22mm internal Diameter Clamp that i'm using for my round (standard) Delrin nut on the Z axis as it may be of use to someone eventually...
Now also included are the files for an X-carriage based on RichRaps Quick-fit type. These files are CC-BY-SA, but be aware that until the MM2 is officially released this may be subject to change at a later date.
This is to comply with Maker's Tool Works intentions for licensing, which can be seen here:
http://www.mendelmax.com/2012/12/27/announcing-the-new-mendelmax-2-0/
"The current plan to do a batch of beta kits to work out any bugs, and then release the sources when version 2.0 is released, probably in Early February. The exact OS license is to be determined, but it will likely be CC-BY-SA."

description.header: Enjoy - and leave comments or suggestions to further this WIP or just let me know what you think... ;)

description.text:
Follow the MM2.0 hardware assembly instructions found here:
http://www.makerstoolworks.com/support-and-docs/assembly-guides/
substituting your printed parts for the laser-cut versions as you go along!
(Dont forget to accomodate for any increased bolt length requirements in the thickened parts) I recommend for a reasonable degree of rigidity, printing these with;
  • AT LEAST 40% infill (pref. honeycomb)
  • AT LEAST 3 shells / perimeters
  • 0.2mm layer height (or less if you can manage it)
  • PLA, Always PLA! (Or indeed another polymer with considerable stiffness- Polycarbonate would be ideal.
    I'd love to see how effective taulmans Nylon is - if anyone has the inclination to try it, please let me know how it goes!)
    • Y BED ASSEMBLY:
    Print one of each component, use the central piece on the bottom to help align the Y rail cars and then add the 'arms' on top of that.
    Bolt firmly, add glass etc and print! Don't forget to report any successes / failures!

comments.author: nEuDy

But then, the complete x cariage with the 2 aluminium extrusions and the x arm plates moves forward in y direction, right? So the middle of the x arm plates, on which the nut for the lead screw nuts is fixed move forward in y direction, or i'm here also wrong?? :-\

So i will give a try to you parts :-)
By the way: greate work of the y bed plate!! Looks nice :-)
comments.author: JEZZMUND

comments.text:
:D
Yes, the whole X carriage assembly technically moves forward a little, but it's such a small amount that I found there was enough breathing room to account for that across the rest of the assembly. there's quite a large amount of tolerance in the lead screw arm / mounting plates so there's no problems there either.
If you DID have any trouble with tolerances the easiest fix by far would be to widen the holes at the ends of each leadscrew arm by approx 1mm - the resulting tolerance shift would more than compensate.
Honestly though - I really doubt this is necessary.
I've used these files to build both a normal and a double sized mendelmax2 and neither had any problems on that front.
My first (V1.0) build had every single part printed at 3mm thickness - but I found that they lacked stability.
I can guarantee you'll have a world of problems on your X carriage if you leave those at 3mm - even at 100% fill.
V1.5 featured most parts at 4 or 5mm thickness, which for the most part was adequate but still suffered from a lot of flex, the upper triangles fatigued quickly, as did the both the X plates.
But at 6mm thickness with a high degree of infill (50% hex) no parts flex and none show any signs of mechanical stress.
Theoretically you could thicken everything up to 8 or 10mm - but that would be seriously overkill, and too large a number of bolts would need changing from the default MM2 BOM.
comments.author: nEuDy

comments.text:
Mine works beautifully, 200+ hours of printing so far with not a single hiccup...
(touch wood / fingers crossed, etc)
seriously though - Not a single glitch or problem so far...

I wouldn't use the printable Y plate - as it's too weak as yet, I suggest printing out a template and jigsawing yourself a version out of plywood. I will continue modifying the Y plate until a printable version works - but i'm not there yet...

These friction tires will hopefully give a better grip... Print using 0.2mm layers. I have included lots of versions with differently sized "loops" so that you can create your own preferred grip depending on your filament/speed etc. ( In the pics I have used PI-ETPU 95-250 Carbon Black http://rubber3dprinting.com/ ) Use the rims found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1103751 This snap-on design is also available for tires/rims that can be used with the OpenR/C Touring Car or similar RC cars naturally. Download the Touring rims here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001223 and the tires here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001233 Enjoy! Please also check out my unuiqe UV-stable, flexible and conductive filament called ETPU 95-250 Carbon Black filament. Don´t need the conductivity? Well the conductivity is great for some things but perhaps not your first choice? Then consider this: This filament will give you some really nice benefits if the conductivity is not an disadvantage for your 3D printed design: •The material composition eliminates “stringing / webbing” issues.
•The hardness of 95 shore A and the carbon black filler makes for great print abilities.
•The carbon black filler is an excellent UV stabilizer thus the prints are built to last in very harsh environments.
•The matte black surface finish has a very exclusive look.
•The material feels very nice and dry to touch.
•It´s not too stretchy and will do great for timing belts etc. http://rubber3dprinting.com/

http://instagram.com/rubber3dprinting

https://grabcad.com/library/openr-c-1-10-formula-1-car-1

Keep in mind that you use my designs on your own risk and that I in no way is responsible for any damage och injuries. https://youtu.be/hIMoa_aeMOU

title: Xmods k8200/3drag streak free Z upgrade

description.text:
My first uploaded piece!
This is my version of a streak free Z upgrade.
No need to buy expencive parts, 95% printable.
All you need is some bolts/nuts and a bearing and ofcourse pulley and belt

Printer:

k8200

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

-

Infill:

-

Notes: The nutbringers have supports in the design, just brake loose after print...

BOM No complete list yet! 6x m8 nuts and washers
2x m4 treaded bolts (approx 55mm long)
2(or4x) m4 lock-nuts (2 if use bolt, 4 if rod)
4x m4 washers, large is prefered
2x ballbearing (one is reusable)
1x spring approx 9mm dia 15mm long (not to hard)
1x GT2 pulley (or T5, but T5 is not tried by me) (I use 20teeth gt2 pulley)
1x GT2 (or T5) belt, will count teeth at next service Parts Motor 1 is sticking out as Pictures Motor 2 is more in front the printer to save some space, motor 2 is not tried by me, not printed.. GT2 nutpulley has 31 teeth Code:

comments.text: Very interesting idea. I had something using this principle working some 15 years ago, but it was a DC motor driving an actuator for a robot that I never finished, and it was using a nut jammed into a gear rather than a belt drive. The anti-backlash spring does seem to follow the right principle, but while it eliminates the backlash between the threaded rod and the gear, it doesn't pick up any possible slack between the gear and the bearings, unless I am missing another preload.

author: Noured

description.text: NEW: Watch me use it on YouTube - https://youtu.be/HCjX-l-UPec Sharp knifes are essential in your kitchen. I was inspired by another 3D printed knife sharpener (http://www.dr-henschke.de/Messerschleifer.html) and adapted the design for relatively cheep Chinese water stones as you can find them on eBay. Additionally I simplified the geometry to reduce the number of parts and to make the assembly easier. The design works very well and I already sharpened dozens of dull knifes. I also include angle gauges which you can use to set the blade angle.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Mendel90

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

10-15%

The stand has integrated supports. Just break them out after printing.
Add an M4 nut in the slot of the guide.
I use a butterfly nut to quickly adjust the position of the holder.
Put 5 8mm neodymium magnets in the holes to hold the knifes. Push them a little bit more in the fixture that they do not scratch the knife and glue them in place.
Use 10mm aluminum rods for the base unit and a 6mm one for the stone holder.

comments.text: Have you made any progress on this since earlier this year? This looks like a great idea.
comments.author: teamwija

comments.text:
Not at the moment - I still face the issue with local heating when applying more power - on the other hand side, if I add more spacing between the capacitor plates I'm not able to get the required capacity.
I'm still working on a few ideas, but at the moment the printer is not working because of technical issues :-(
comments.author: teamwija

comments.text: Do you get heating towards the corners? That seems like where you'd get weird results if anywhere.
comments.author: dhg864

comments.text:
No, it's not the corners (of course the create lossy stray capacity). The issue is the not constant distance between the plates. If you apply some power, there is local heating. This softens the PLA and weakens the isolation tape - leading to a changed capacity in the end.
For my MagLoops, the capacity fading is critical as they are very narrow band.
comments.author: teamwija

comments.text: Can you print in PETG or ABS? I've got both and they've got vastly more dimensional stability at temperatures below their glass transition. Alternately, I can imagine using a 2x4 wrapped in copper tape as the center element for a trombone varicap.
comments.author: dhg864

comments.text:
I'm using a thin self adhesive copper tape ... so it's not a good choice to transport / distribute heat and also not optimal for HF. Printing ABS is not possible (because of fumes) and PETG might be an option, but I never tried it (because for most times, I print my master in PLA and create a resin cast out of it).
The heat points are random as my IR camera tells me :-)
I think the design components are the issue:
Use thicker copper foil and most of the issues might be gone.
Maybe you have an idea for another design which can handle more HF power? I thing we should go more to the "cola can capacitor",
comments.author: teamwija

comments.text: My hope is to do 100W, which seems to require a ~5kV varicap for tuning, which is unfortunately pretty pricey. I've been thinking that I could use PLA washers as a dielectric / spacer to get more power handling on a butterfly varicap, but that's the only idea I've got so far.
comments.author: dhg864

comments.text:
5kV for 100W might be to low. The more effective (high Q) your antenna is, the higher the voltage.
PLA might be a good isolator, but it strongly depends on the PLA itself. My best experience is with clear/nature or white PLA. Others contain color particles that might have an impact on the HF (like carbon or metal particles).
If you use PLA as washers, think of sealing it in epoxy or acrylic to keep moisture out of it.
comments.author: teamwija

comments.text:
Give it a try. I always do two tests:
1) Will the material (and the microwave) survive a full power transmission (800W inside the microwave) without melting, or sparking
2) Insert the material into a coil and measure Q and inductance. If Q is affected, the material is bad because it's lossy by eddy currents. If Inductance raises a lot, it's not harmfull, but keep in mind when using it near HF lines.
comments.author: dhg864

comments.text: Maybe ABS would be a better choice for the lack of hygroscopy...
comments.author: dhg864

comments.text:
A small update:
While testing it turned out, the capacity is not perfectly reproduceable. I'm currently working on another split capacitor design with the goal to have a >5kV reproduceable split capacitor for e.g. Shortwave Small Transmitting (Magnetic) Loop Antennas.
comments.author: dhg864

comments.text:
At 5kv you are not shooting for QRP I guess? Keep in mind that the 1mm per kv is a best case scenario in dessicated air! If you want
to run 5kv into an air variable in the real world, you'll want more like 10mm between the plates. I'd like to see this work and am also
working on some ideas, hit me up on qrz (n3glv).
comments.author: dhg864

comments.text:
Hi,
I know the 1kv/mm is the critical minimum and it's only for DC-like voltages.
Of course my design is not aiming for QRP only - I'm still searching for for "home made" solutions, but no one is working currently as expected.
My main goal is to rely an 3D printing and house hold materials to be as efficient as possible. And this means for me, I'm aiming for something like 20W-50W constant power.
The best I got until now is a combination of copper foil and capton tape (with no air gap). If you implement an air gap, the combination of the both dielectric components increase the field in the air. So my tests show two possibilities:
1) Only air as dielectricum between the plates with a 1kv/mm minimum - design is big for bigger capacities
2) Only Capton tape as dielectricum - here the local distance is critical as it builds up hot spots when applying HF power. And hotspots produce runaway effects.
But experimenting with the MagLoop design, I'm very successful with an oversized MagLoop (or a capacitive shorted circle dipole) with a circumfence of about .4 Lambda. The voltage across the capacity is lower, die convered surface of the loop is bigger - and in practice I use this as monoband antenna for 15m with great success from inside the house (QRP - but also 40W did not burn a RG58 capacitor which is limited to about 1kV)
Sorry, I'm not really active on qrz. I just sent you a mail (check spam, as I'm using a mail relay)
comments.author: n3glv

description.text:
Here are my STL files for my DIY Hotas project. 
This is not a plug-and-play project. You need loads of auxiliary parts to get it working.  You need bolts, bearings, magnets, hall sensors. You also need to come up with your own joystick base (or mount), grip design, electronics.
Hole dimension for bolts and bearings were hand-adjusted in the technical designs to match the hardware. It most certainly will not make a perfect fit on your own printer.

description.text: This DIY filament spool can easily be adjusted by different rod lengths or arm sizes. The current design is made for 8mm threaded rods between the center and the arms. You also need two 608 bearings for the center part. I tried around 3kg of filament on the big version with 13cm long threaded rods. Works just fine and helps to avoid tangled up filament. We also offer the small version in our webshop: http://www.cubic-print.com/DIY-Filament-Spool

This servo saver is designed to protect the gears inside of a servo by twisting or breaking in the event of a large shock. These are commonly used on RC vehicles and robots that experience rough environments.
Each arm features 3mm diameter holes and should be compatible with most linkages. I have also created a version with 1.5mm holes if needed.
I DO NOT guarantee or warranty the effectiveness of this device in protecting your servos. Use with caution.
If you like this project or want to know more about 3D printing, check out my new book "The Makerspace Workbench" from Maker Media!

description.text:
A simple SD car holder I made for my printer.
At present, I do basically all of my printing from the SD card slot. The two slots here would allow me to use one as an "inbox" and the other as an "outbox." That way, I can queue up printing, and have a stack of SD cards ready to be loaded up with gcode for other ones.
That's the idea, anyway. :P
I just glued it to the side of the printer using a glue stick.

This geared extruder was designed from scratch, because i want to use small nema17 motor for bowden. I have test without gear, it cannot deliver enough force. Ratio is 7:32, it use 624 for idler and 2x625 for 5mm hex nut shaft. For the drive gear, it use standard MK8 drive gear
On idler plastic there is place for M4 nut, it use to lock the 4mm ptfe tube for filament out. Items:
M5 Hex bolt 3-4cm
MK8 gear
1x M5 spacer, 2x M5 nut
2x M3 to mount body to motor
1x M4 need to cut short for idler.
2x 625 for shaft bearing
1x 624 for idler.
1xM4 nut To make tensior, i use steel from PEG to clamp
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-7Bpu9PBq18
